div.p: Greetings. I believe you have received my letters, which I wrote to you eight days ago.

I sent along excerpts from letters I had received from Italy. Now, my son, understanding that he is traveling to you, could not restrain his hand from the pen. I also, so that there would be something to write, wanted to inform you that I have received letters from the Bishop of Rennes, in which he indicates that three major princes agree on the Council of Trent; the question remains whether a new convocation should be made or the continuation of the last one, which the Pope insists on. The Emperor wants to give his daughter to the Duke of Mantua.
I believe the King has recovered from his cold and that everything will be quieter in France. My wife sends her regards to you and all our friends.
To Lord Heinrich Bullinger, the most vigilant pastor of the Church of Zürich.
